Confirm that the email(s): are in the correct format (john@aaa.com) are separated with a comma, semicolon or space (john@aaa.com, jane@bbb.com) have no more than 3 recipients listed Message (optional) This message cannot be sent, because it includes the following invalid URL shorteners: Gift article SHARE LINK Copy Download Print Gift article Exxon lifts force majeure on its giant Mozambique LNG project The force majeure was put in place after Islamic State-affiliated militants carried out an attack near its operations in northeastern Mozambique in 2021. By:  Bloomberg Close tooltip X Icon × Bloomberg Contributor | 11/21/2025 06:45 AM EST ENERGYWIRE | Exxon Mobil lifted a force majeure on its Rovuma liquefied natural gas project in Mozambique as security concerns subside, a key step toward sanctioning the development and committing construction funds. The force majeure was put in place after Islamic State-affiliated militants carried out an attack near its operations in northeastern Mozambique in 2021. Ending the force majeure will allow work to resume and is a crucial step toward Exxon making a final investment decision on the project, which is expected next year. TotalEnergies, which is building a separate $20 billion LNG plant nearby, ended its own suspension last month. "We have lifted force majeure for the Rovuma LNG project,” an Exxon spokesman said. “We are working with our partners and the government of Mozambique to ensure the safety of our people and facilities, as we look to develop a world-class LNG project that can help drive economic growth.” The Exxon and TotalEnergies projects are expected to be online by the early 2030s — assuming no further delays — and will enable Mozambique to ship gas around the world for decades. They also promise to transform the country’s economy, one of the world’s poorest, into an energy-export powerhouse. ... Continue reading this article. contents.title: Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill - Stand.earth
contents.content: Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill - Stand.earth Donate About About Us Our Story Our Approach Financials Staff & Board Job Opportunities Contact Our Work What We Do How We Do It Our Campaigns Get Involved Donate Take Action Join Our Community Insights & Press Research Group Reports & Resources Donate About Us Our Story Our Approach Staff & Board Job Opportunities Financials FAQ Contact Our Work What We Do How We Do It Our Campaigns Research Group Insights & Press Reports & Resources Take Action Donate ©  2004 - 2025 Stand.earth | Privacy Policy | Copyright Policy | Customer service: ChatBot , HelpDesk , KnowledgeBase & LiveChat Website by Studio Lake Press Releases Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill November 19, 2025 OTTAWA | TRADITIONAL, UNCEDED TERRITORY OF THE ALGONQUIN ANISHNAABEG PEOPLE – While governments and civil society meet in Brazil for COP30 to address the climate emergency, Prime Minister Mark Carney and Alberta Premier Danielle Smith are advancing the most controversial fossil fuel project in Canadian history – a dirty tar sands bitumen pipeline from Alberta to the B.C. coast. This financially unsound project, already stopped once , risks First Nations and civil society opposition and international condemnation, and is a complete break with Canadians’ efforts to advance Indigenous Reconciliation and climate commitments. In 2016, after years of Indigenous and civil society opposition and legal challenges, the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline – which would have transported 500,000 barrels of toxic bitumen oil per day – was halted. In 2019, a federal moratorium on oil tankers in coastal waters of B.C. stretching from the northern tip of Vancouver Island to Alaska was enacted in law, affirming the critical value of this region to coastal communities, First Nations, and marine life. An informal moratorium had been in place since 1972. At the UN climate talks in Brazil, over 80 countries are calling for a roadmap to transition away from fossil fuels. And some, from China to Pakistan, are making unprecedented leaps forward in renewable energy generation, particularly solar power. By contrast, Canada is moving in the wrong direction, expanding fossil fuel production, including recently announcing support for two new liquified methane gas (LNG) facilities . Fossil fuels are the single largest driver of human-caused climate change. Liz McDowell, Stand.earth Senior Campaigns Director, said: “Any attempt to build another pipeline to move the dirtiest oil on the planet through one of the most ecologically fragile places on Earth will be met with an opposition that will make the Trans Mountain, Enbridge and Keystone XL protests look like a kid’s birthday party. Every climate and social justice civil society organization on these lands, and beyond, will be tireless and dogged in our resistance. This is not just about Canadian wildfires and droughts, this is about fossil-fueled storms decimating nations like Jamaica and the Philippines, and entire islands sinking due to rising seas. Lawsuits will be filed. Protests will fill the streets and the halls of government. We will mobilize nationally and internationally to rise for legally-protected Indigenous rights.” Regarding Northern Gateway 2.0 , Kiki Wood , Senior Campaigner with Stand.earth said: “Danielle Smith doesn’t seem to understand that ‘no’ means ‘no’. Advancing a dirty tar sands bitumen oil pipeline through sacred temperate rainforest and unceded territory, trampling Indigenous rights while world leaders meet to tackle the climate crisis is a stab in the back, a traitorous offense, a disappearance of leadership, and morally repugnant. The Trans Mountain tar sands oil pipeline cost taxpayers $35 billion and it still isn’t operating at full capacity. With global oil demand projected to tail off, why would we need another pipeline? People living in B.C., including Coastal First Nations, have been clear, we are not willing to risk another Exxon Valdez-sized tanker disaster. Canada has the chance to invest in clean energy and protecting nature, not doubling down on the very fuels driving wildfires, floods, deadly heat and droughts.” Regarding the rolling back the tanker ban, Anna Barford, Oceans Campaigner with Stand.earth, said: “Setting the tanker ban adrift means losing billions of dollars in the ocean economy by exponentially increasing the timeline for the big oil spill. Tankers inevitably have accidents that lead to spills, which are impossible to clean up. Tar sands products are sticky and sink, the impact from a spill will last generations within the ecosystem, which is why the ban was in place to begin with. Removing the decades long protections against a worst case scenario oil spill is an act of designating a sacrifice zone for tar sands prosperity.” Regarding moving ahead with carbon capture and storage technology (CCUS) , Sven Biggs, Oil and Gas Campaign Director with Stand.earth said: “Carbon capture and storage is nothing more than another subsidy for the fossil fuel industry and an excuse to keep burning oil and gas. The federal government has already spent $9.1 billion on it at the behest of the fossil fuel industry only to show that it’s costly, unproven at scale, and to date has captured roughly 0.5% of national emissions. Either way, carbon capture is not a solution to the majority of fossil fuel emissions, which come from burning oil, gas, and coal by the end user.” Liz McDowell, Stand.earth Senior Campaigns Director, added: “In just months Carney has undone a decade of climate progress, dragging Canada back to the Harper years. This shortsighted focus on expanding oil and gas is only going to hurt Canadians. While other countries are making unprecedented leaps in renewable energy production, Canada’s stuck in the past – and we’re going to get left behind.” ###### Contact Liz McDowell, Senior Campaigns Director – Stand.earth +1 604-219-6337, liz@stand.earth (Pacific Time) Sven Biggs, Canadian Oil and Gas Programs Director – Stand.earth +1 778-882-8354, sven@stand.earth (Pacific Time) Richard Brooks, Climate Finance Director – Stand.earth +1 416-573-7209, richard@stand.earth (Eastern Time) Kiki Wood, Senior Oil and Gas Campaigner – Stand.earth +1 604-367-1865, kiki@stand.earth   (Pacific Time) Arin de Hoog, Communications, Oil, Gas and Shipping – Stand.earth. +1 613-978-7329, arin.dehoog@stand.earth (Eastern Time) Latest Insights & Press Shareholder Proposal Seeks Board Committee to Address Wells Fargo’s Indigenous Peoples’ Rights Risks November 20, 2025 Carney’s deal with the devil: a deadly tar sands pipeline through B.C., violating Indigenous rights and risking another Exxon Valdez oil spill November 19, 2025 As COP30 meets in Brazil, 62 faith institutions announce fossil fuel divestment commitments November 18, 2025 View All Share Related Second annual report analyzes major public pensions’ responses to the climate crisis in proxy voting Learn More Berkeley adopts first-of-its-kind policy to cut pollution from existing homes Learn More New report finds Microsoft’s AI data center demand to surge 600%, require as much power as entire New England region Learn More Our Financials 85% of all our expenses go to our programs Learn More Join the Stand.earth community and raise the bar on climate action Start Here Want to join our community? Log in Free Trial Search → Trump's Law S.1582: $21T Dollar Revolution Coming (From Brownstone Research) (Ad) Willis Investment Counsel Acquires 17,246 Shares of Exxon Mobil Corporation $XOM Written by MarketBeat November 21, 2025 Share Link copied to clipboard. Image from MarketBeat Media, LLC. Key Points Willis Investment Counsel increased its stake in Exxon Mobil by 8.2%, buying 17,246 shares to hold 227,789 shares valued at $24,556,000, making XOM about 1.4% of the firm's holdings and its 25th-largest position. Exxon raised its quarterly dividend to $1.03 (annualized $4.12), a yield of roughly 3.5%, with an ex-dividend date of November 14 and a payout ratio near 60%. Analyst sentiment is a consensus "Moderate Buy" with a mean price target of $128.67, reflecting a mix of ratings (2 Strong Buy, 8 Buy, 10 Hold). MarketBeat previews the top five stocks to own by December 1st . Willis Investment Counsel raised its holdings in shares of Exxon Mobil Corporation ( NYSE:XOM - Free Report ) by 8.2% in the second quarter, according to its most recent 13F filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The fund owned 227,789 shares of the oil and gas company's stock after purchasing an additional 17,246 shares during the period. Exxon Mobil accounts for about 1.4% of Willis Investment Counsel's holdings, making the stock its 25th largest holding. Willis Investment Counsel's holdings in Exxon Mobil were worth $24,556,000 at the end of the most recent quarter. 3 Energy Giants Amp Up Dividends—Here’s What It Means for Investors Other large investors have also recently made changes to their positions in the company. Journey Strategic Wealth LLC increased its stake in shares of Exxon Mobil by 6.7% in the 1st quarter. Journey Strategic Wealth LLC now owns 21,929 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $2,608,000 after acquiring an additional 1,379 shares in the last quarter. Linscomb Wealth Inc. grew its holdings in Exxon Mobil by 1.4% in the second quarter. Linscomb Wealth Inc. now owns 389,769 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $42,017,000 after purchasing an additional 5,527 shares during the period. Jones Financial Companies Lllp grew its holdings in Exxon Mobil by 52.3% in the first quarter. Jones Financial Companies Lllp now owns 382,989 shares of the oil and gas company's stock worth $45,149,000 after purchasing an additional 131,600 shares during the period. OneAscent Wealth Management LLC increased its stake in shares of Exxon Mobil by 116.7% during the second quarter. OneAscent Wealth Management LLC now owns 7,657 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $825,000 after purchasing an additional 4,123 shares in the last quarter. Finally, Phoenix Financial Ltd. lifted its holdings in shares of Exxon Mobil by 23.9% during the first quarter. Phoenix Financial Ltd. now owns 97,050 shares of the oil and gas company's stock valued at $11,561,000 after purchasing an additional 18,752 shares during the last quarter. 61.80% of the stock is currently owned by institutional investors. Get Exxon Mobil alerts: Sign Up Exxon Mobil Price Performance NYSE XOM opened at $117.04 on Friday. Exxon Mobil Corporation has a one year low of $97.80 and a one year high of $123.21. The stock has a 50-day moving average of $114.59 and a 200 day moving average of $110.95. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.12, a quick ratio of 0.88 and a current ratio of 1.25. Log in Free Trial Search → A Message From An Ex-CIA Officer About Trump (From Paradigm Press) (Ad) Mediolanum International Funds Ltd Sells 23,688 Shares of Exxon Mobil Corporation $XOM Written by MarketBeat November 21, 2025 Share Link copied to clipboard. Image from MarketBeat Media, LLC. Key Points Mediolanum International Funds Ltd trimmed its stake in Exxon Mobil by 3.3% in Q2, selling 23,688 shares and now holding 698,051 shares worth about $76.35 million, roughly 0.9% of its portfolio and the fund's 16th-largest position. Exxon increased its quarterly dividend to $1.03 (from $0.99), payable Dec. 10 with record/ex-dividend dates on Nov. 14, implying a $4.12 annualized payout and a yield near 3.5% (payout ratio ~59.9%). Exxon reported $0.65 EPS and $57.55 billion in revenue for the quarter; analysts expect full-year EPS of 7.43 and the consensus price target is $128.67 with an average rating of "Moderate Buy." Interested in Exxon Mobil? Here are five stocks we like better . contents.content: Exxon to acquire 40% stake in enterprise Bahia NGL pipeline | News.az --> We value your privacy We use cookies to enhance your browsing experience, serve personalised ads or content, and analyse our traffic. Reject All Save My Preferences Accept All Powered by News.az Toggle Navigation Politics Azerbaijan Opinion Region Analytics World Economics Interviews exclusives Central Asia COP29 Ukraine and Russia at war Middle East Culture Tourism Sports Photos Video Crypto India Evergreen Currency Converter News Economics Exxon to acquire 40% stake in enterprise Bahia NGL pipeline 20 Nov 2025 16:47 338 --> 1040660 Economics Share https://news.az/news/exxon-to-acquire-40-stake-in-enterprise-bahia-ngl-pipeline Copied Photo: Reuters + ↺ − 16 px Exxon Mobil Corp will acquire a 40% stake in the Bahia natural gas liquids (NGL) pipeline, operated by Enterprise Products Partners, the companies announced Thursday. The 550-mile pipeline, currently in commissioning, is expected to begin commercial operations soon. It will initially transport 600,000 barrels per day (bpd) of mixed NGLs from the Midland and Delaware basins to Enterprise’s Mont Belvieu fractionation hub in Texas , News.Az reports, citing Reuters . The transaction is expected to close by early 2026, further strengthening Exxon’s midstream presence in the U.S. energy sector.   News.Az   --> exxon bahia bahia ngl bahia ngl pipeline enterprise products partners --> --> Similar news Economics Georgia-Azerbaijan trade turnover rises by over 2% This is 2.2% more compared to the same period in 2024, News.Az reports, citing local media. Azerbaijan's share in Georg... Economics French lawmakers reject tax measures in 2026 budget bill ahead of Senate review Both chambers must approve the budget for it to pass without the government invoking special constitutional powers. Afte...
